articles.headline: Who Discriminates in Hiring? A New Study Can Tell.
articles.snippet: Applications seemingly from Black candidates got fewer replies than those evidently from white candidates. The method could point to specific companies.
articles.abstract: Applications seemingly from Black candidates got fewer replies than those evidently from white candidates. The method could point to specific companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Kalisha White performed an experiment. A Marquette University graduate who is Black, she suspected that her application for a job as executive team leader at a Target in Wisconsin was being ignored because of her race. So she sent in another one, with a name (Sarah Brucker) more likely to make the candidate appear white.

articles.headline: Robinhood’s Shares Fall 8.4% in Public Trading Debut
articles.snippet: The stock opened at $38, the same as its I.P.O. price. The price’s drop was a sign of investor hesitancy over a company that has attracted regulatory scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The stock opened at $38, the same as its I.P.O. price. The price’s drop was a sign of investor hesitancy over a company that has attracted regulatory scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Robinhood helped propel a “meme stock” frenzy this year that sent share prices of small companies on a roller-coaster ride. On Thursday, its own initial public offering was far more subdued.

articles.headline: Activision, Facing Internal Turmoil, Grapples With #MeToo Reckoning
articles.snippet: More than 1,500 employees for the video game giant, which is facing an explosive state lawsuit, have called for executives to take sexual harassment seriously.
articles.abstract: More than 1,500 employees for the video game giant, which is facing an explosive state lawsuit, have called for executives to take sexual harassment seriously.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 1,500 workers for the video game maker Activision Blizzard walked out from their jobs this week. Thousands signed a letter rebuking their employer. And even as the chief executive apologized, current and former employees said they would not stop raising a ruckus.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Ex-Cardinal McCarrick Faces Milestone Charges in Catholic Sex Abuse Crisis
articles.snippet: Theodore McCarrick, 91, is the highest-ranking U.S. official in the Roman Catholic Church to be charged with sexual abuse. He is accused of assaulting a 16-year-old boy in 1974.
articles.abstract: Theodore McCarrick, 91, is the highest-ranking U.S. official in the Roman Catholic Church to be charged with sexual abuse. He is accused of assaulting a 16-year-old boy in 1974.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wedding reception took place on a June weekend in 1974. But it was this week that Theodore E. McCarrick, the former Roman Catholic cardinal expelled by Pope Francis, was criminally charged with repeatedly sexually assaulting a teenage boy at the event.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias, Ruth Graham and Liam Stack

articles.headline: How Europe, After a Fumbling Start, Overtook the U.S. in Vaccination
articles.snippet: Just a few months ago, European Union efforts were a mess, but its problems were temporary. The United States turned out to have the more lasting challenge.
articles.abstract: Just a few months ago, European Union efforts were a mess, but its problems were temporary. The United States turned out to have the more lasting challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few months ago, European Union efforts were a mess, but its problems were temporary. The United States turned out to have the more lasting challenge.
articles.byline: By Elian Peltier and Josh Holder

articles.headline: Biden Seeks to Revive Vaccine Effort With New Rules and Incentives
articles.snippet: The president said those refusing to get a coronavirus shot should expect inconveniences as long as they decline a vaccine.
articles.abstract: The president said those refusing to get a coronavirus shot should expect inconveniences as long as they decline a vaccine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday sought to revive the nation’s stalled push to vaccinate Americans against the surging Delta variant of the coronavirus, announcing new requirements for federal workers to be vaccinated and urging local and state governments to offer $100 to anyone willing to get a shot voluntarily.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Annie Karni

articles.headline: How Biden Got the Infrastructure Deal Trump Couldn’t
articles.snippet: The early success of the deal vindicated the president’s faith in bipartisanship. If he can keep it on track, it will help affirm the rationale for his presidency.
articles.abstract: The early success of the deal vindicated the president’s faith in bipartisanship. If he can keep it on track, it will help affirm the rationale for his presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s success at propelling an infrastructure deal past its first major hurdle this week was a vindication of his faith in bipartisanship and a repudiation of the slash-and-burn politics of his immediate predecessor, President Donald J. Trump, who tried and failed to block it.

articles.headline: Why Elite Female Athletes Are Turning Away From Major Sponsors
articles.snippet: Smaller brands are working with athletes in different ways, like giving them equity or roles in developing products, and are paying more attention to their personal stories.
articles.abstract: Smaller brands are working with athletes in different ways, like giving them equity or roles in developing products, and are paying more attention to their personal stories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Athleta, the activewear brand for women and girls owned by Gap Inc., had never sponsored an athlete when it approached the six-time Olympic champion sprinter Allyson Felix in 2019, shortly after she took Nike to task for its pay practices for pregnant runners.

articles.headline: China Targets Costly Tutoring Classes. Parents Want to Save Them.
articles.snippet: Many families and experts say Beijing’s education overhaul will help the rich and make the system even more competitive for those who can barely afford it.
articles.abstract: Many families and experts say Beijing’s education overhaul will help the rich and make the system even more competitive for those who can barely afford it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zhang Hongchun worries that his 10-year-old daughter isn’t getting enough sleep. Between school, homework and after-school guitar, clarinet and calligraphy practice, most nights she doesn’t get to bed before 11. Some of her classmates keep going until midnight.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Nooses, Anger and No Answers: Inside the Uproar Over a Future Amazon Site
articles.snippet: The discovery of multiple nooses has set off heated debates about the responsibility of companies and the ability of workers to speak their mind.
articles.abstract: The discovery of multiple nooses has set off heated debates about the responsibility of companies and the ability of workers to speak their mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, Conn. — The town of Windsor has developed a niche in the world of warehouses and manufacturing, taking advantage of wide open spaces and crisscrossing interstates in nearby Hartford. Walgreens has a large facility here, as does Dollar Tree.

articles.headline: ‘They Thought I Was Dead’: Haitian President’s Widow Recounts Assassination
articles.snippet: Struck by gunfire, Martine Moïse lay bleeding as the assassins who killed her husband ransacked her room. Now, she says, the F.B.I. must find the mastermind behind the attack.
articles.abstract: Struck by gunfire, Martine Moïse lay bleeding as the assassins who killed her husband ransacked her room. Now, she says, the F.B.I. must find the mastermind behind the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With her elbow shattered by gunfire and her mouth full of blood, the first lady of Haiti lay on the floor beside her bed, unable to breathe, as the assassins stormed the room.

articles.headline: They Spurned the Vaccine. Now They Want You to Know They Regret It.
articles.snippet: People who once rejected the vaccine or simply waited too long are now grappling with the consequences, often in raw, public ways.
articles.abstract: People who once rejected the vaccine or simply waited too long are now grappling with the consequences, often in raw, public ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: PROVO, Utah — As Mindy Greene spent another day in the Covid intensive care unit, listening to the whirring machines that now breathed for her 42-year-old husband, Russ, she opened her phone and tapped out a message.

articles.headline: Trump Pressed Justice Dept. to Declare Election Results Corrupt, Notes Show
articles.snippet: “Leave the rest to me” and to congressional allies, the former president is said to have told top law enforcement officials.
articles.abstract: “Leave the rest to me” and to congressional allies, the former president is said to have told top law enforcement officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump pressed top Justice Department officials late last year to declare that the election was corrupt even though they had found no instances of widespread fraud, so he and his allies in Congress could use the assertion to try to overturn the results, according to new documents provided to lawmakers.
